SENT.plain: AIM: To explore the effect of basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) on focal cerebral ischemic injury and antioxidant enzyme activities
METHODS: Rats underwent 24-h middle cerebral artery occlusion by intraluminal suture
Infarction volume was shown with staining and quantitated by image analysis system
Neurologic deficit scores were determined with a 0-5 grade scale
Antioxidant enzyme activities of forebrains were detected
RESULTS: bFGF (45 micrograms.kg-1.h-1 i.v. for 3 h, started 5 min after the onset of ischemia) showed potent neuroprotective effects
Infarction volumes were decreased from 272 mm3 +/- 22 mm3 (saline-treated) to 201 mm3 +/- 30 mm3 (bFGF-treated)
Neurologic deficit scores were decreased from 3.6 +/- 1.5 (saline-treated) to 2.3 +/- 1.6 (bFGF-treated)

Focal cerebral ischemia induced an increase in the activities of catalase (CAT), superoxide dismutase (SOD), glutathione peroxidase (GSH-PX), but a decrease in the level of glutathione s-transferase (GSH-ST)
Treatment of bFGF further increased the CAT activity but had no effect on the activities of SOD, GSH-PX, and GSH-ST
CONCLUSION: bFGF has a neuroprotective effect against focal cerebral ischemic injury
The elevation of CAT activity by bFGF may be involved in this effect
